text:
Human babies are helpless little things that
depend on a lot of care for a very long time.

But we humans aren’t the only ones who can’t
make it on our own.

Some animal babies -- mostly birds, but some
mammals, too -- are usually cared for by two parents.
Others rely only on the care of their mothers.

But probably the rarest form of parental care
among other animals comes in the form of the
single dad.
Take the giant water bug, for example.

In general, parental care of any kind is pretty
rare among insects, but /paternal/ care is

nearly unheard of, with only thirteen known
exceptions.

Found in freshwater ponds throughout the northern
United States and Canada, giant water bugs

can be up to ten centimeters long, and are
sometimes charmingly referred to as “toe biters.”

And it’s pretty easy to pick a giant water
bug dad out of the crowd, because he is the
one covered in eggs.

See, once they mate, the female deposits and
glues 100 or more eggs on the male’s back
before peacing out.

And even though it makes it harder for him
to hunt for prey and easier to /get/ caught,

he’ll schlep those eggs around until they
hatch.

He’ll also comb his legs through them every
now and then to keep them clean and free of

fungal infection, and make sure to air them
out at the water’s surface.

Now, piggy-backing your offspring is one thing,
but imagine carrying a bunch of squirmy babies
around in your mouth!

That’s basically what South American Darwin’s
frog fathers do.

The female deposits her eggs on the ground
in moist leaf-litter, where the male fertilizes them.

Then, she hops off, and the male keeps watch
over the eggs for the next three weeks.

Once the growing larvae start wiggling around
inside the their eggs, he swallows them -- not

as a snack, but to hold them in his pouch-like
vocal sac.

A few days later, the eggs hatch into tadpoles
-- but they stay inside the papa frog’s

pouch for 50-70 more days as they gradually
develop into something more frog-shaped.

Once they’re fully transformed, but the
froglets leave the vocal sac and then just

hop out into the world through their dad’s
mouth.

But when it comes to paternal care that goes
above and beyond, one group of dads really
takes the prize.

They don’t just sit on their eggs, or carry
them on their backs, or in their mouths -- they
actually get pregnant and give birth.
Sort of.
I’m talking about seahorses.

As seahorse mating pairs get frisky, the female
deposits her eggs into a special pouch on

the male’s stomach -- called the brood pouch
-- as the male releases sperm to fertilize them.

Then, the male carries the eggs for the 10-25
day gestation period, depending on the species,

providing nutrients and oxygen, as well as
helping the embryos balance their fluids and salts.

Once the babies are fully-developed, the male
experiences abdominal contractions that help

shoot the teeny-tiny seahorses out of the
pouch and into the ocean.

Now, the animals we’ve talked about so far
put a lot of time and energy into taking care
of their developing young.

But once the water bugs, frogs, and seahorses
emerge, the dad’s involvement is over, and
they go off into the world on their own.
Emus do things a little differently.

These large, flightless Australian birds are
often polyandrous, meaning they’ll court
and mate with multiple partners.

Once a female lays a clutch of up to 24 eggs,
her work is done and she’s free to cruise
for other males or do whatever else she wants.

Meanwhile, her mate’s job is just beginning,
and he’s literally not going anywhere.

During the 7-8 week incubation period, males
don’t eat, drink, or pee or poop.

Instead, they carefully tend to their eggs,
padding the nest with dried grasses and gently

rotating the eggs every few hours to make
sure each one gets enough heat.

Once they hatch, chicks stay with their fathers
for nearly seven months, as he teaches them

how to forage for food while aggressively
chasing off anyone who gets too close, including
their mother.

For all of these animal dads, caring for offspring
can take up a lot of resources.

But in the process, they’re helping increase
their young’s chance of survival.

Plus, they get to show any females in the
area that they make good parents, increasing

their chances of pumping more of their genes
into their world during the next breeding season.

So all that investment, in the end, is worth
it.
